results.title: Cinema orchestras and organs
results.brief_description: Melbourne’s Capitol Theatre became the home of the first large Wurlitzer Organ in the country, which was used to provide music and sound effects for silent films when the orchestra was not performing, while the Palais Pictures theatre had its own in-house orchestra.

constellations_primary.name: Sound and cinema
constellations_primary.description: Beginning with one of the first films to be screened at the Palais (a Melbourne cinema with its own outstanding resident orchestra) the constellation celebrates sound as an integral part of the connection between moving image work and audience.

results.description: Melbourne’s The Capitol Theatre is a historic landmark, visited not just by tourists but lovers of film. Designed by Walter Burley Griffin and Marion Mahoney Griffin, it opened on Swanston Street in 1924 and was the first large picture palace in Victoria. It also became the home of the first large Wurlitzer Organ in the country, which was used to provide music and sound effects for silent films when the orchestra was not performing. Across the city, St Kilda’s Palais Pictures opened in 1927 and had its own in-house orchestra. During World War II when there was a shortage of men, an all-female orchestra took over and performed at the Palais up until 1949.
description_for_label: Melbourne’s The Capitol Theatre is a historic landmark, visited not just by tourists but lovers of film. Designed by Walter Burley Griffin and Marion Mahoney Griffin, it opened on Swanston Street in 1924 and was the first large picture palace in Victoria. It also became the home of the first large Wurlitzer Organ in the country, which was used to provide music and sound effects for silent films when the orchestra was not performing. Across the city, St Kilda’s Palais Pictures opened in 1927 and had its own in-house orchestra. During World War II when there was a shortage of men, an all-female orchestra took over and performed at the Palais up until 1949.

results.title: Vitaphone discs
results.brief_description: When Western Electric developed the Vitaphone for Warner Brothers, it changed movies forever. Early filmmakers experimented with sound but couldn’t match it perfectly with motion pictures. The Vitaphone solved that, creating synchronised playback through a vinyl disc manually linked to a film projector.

constellations_primary.name: Sound and Hollywood
constellations_primary.description: The impact of sound on Tinsel Town stretches from the beginning of cinema to recent award-winners, as well as the biggest band in K-Pop.

results.description: When Western Electric developed the Vitaphone for Warner Brothers, it changed movies forever. Early filmmakers experimented with sound but couldn’t match it perfectly with motion pictures. The Vitaphone solved that, creating synchronised playback through a vinyl disc manually linked to a film projector. The system received wide-spread acclaim from its use in the first Vitaphone feature, Don Juan (1926), which featured a synced score from the New York Philharmonic and sound effects, and then a year later in The Jazz Singer, the first film to feature dialogue. Warner Brothers billed the Vitaphone as “the marvel of this marvellous age” and it certainly ushered in a new one: the success of Don Juan and The Jazz Singer signalled the end of silent cinema.
description_for_label: When Western Electric developed the Vitaphone for Warner Brothers, it changed movies forever. Early filmmakers experimented with sound but couldn’t match it perfectly with motion pictures. The Vitaphone solved that, creating synchronised playback through a vinyl disc manually linked to a film projector. The system received wide-spread acclaim from its use in the first Vitaphone feature, Don Juan (1926), which featured a synced score from the New York Philharmonic and sound effects, and then a year later in The Jazz Singer, the first film to feature dialogue. Warner Brothers billed the Vitaphone as “the marvel of this marvellous age” and it certainly ushered in a new one: the success of Don Juan and The Jazz Singer signalled the end of silent cinema.

results.title: Vitaphone Records photograph featuring Tess Horaty
results.credit_line: Courtesy George Rinhart / Corbis via Getty Images
results.brief_description:
Vitaphone Records
(Original Caption) Our photo shows Miss Tess Horaty checking up on Vitaphone Records at the company’s place in Chicago. Since the installation of the machines in various theaters it is extremely hard for the Vitaphone company to meet the supply and demand for the records.
